title: How to write a story where the protagonist does not get what they want - Quora

response.answer_text: How do I write a story where the protagonist does not get what they want? A few tricks come to mind: Think of some people you’ve known or simply heard about over your lifetime, and recall what these people wanted - and I mean, wanted badly - and didn’t get. Not only didn’t they get this person, job, house, result, sports position, answer to a question, and so on and on - but they have a definite reaction to not getting the “whatever,” and part of the story is how they react, what they say, what they, how they redirect their desire, anything that will wind up your story in a satisfactory way, though not necessarily a happily-ever-after way.Keep in mind that a protagonist really doesn’t always get what they want in the world of fiction or nonfiction. “Not getting their way” can easily be a theme in your story; you have conflict, and strife, success and failure, enlightenment, shocking realization, and so on. They’re just people (unless they’re not); therefore, anything can happen.Your protagonist can earn his/her keep by showing throughout the story the various outcomes from similar behavior, the pros and cons of anything, can display within the narrative many sides to his/her personality, emotional makeup, intelligence, etc., and that not all methods are successful to all people.Admit that your protagonist may not always be a sentient being; it may be an idea, a concept, a goal, a belief, anything one can’t touch but creates deep feelings toward. Maybe like a campaign to save a 200-year-old tree; the tree isn’t the protagonist - the movement to save the tree is that.I like to remember that the Universe isn’t only made up of what Earthlings view as “life”, but of anything that stands as a whole to be challenged or accepted.Hope this helps. Best of luck.

One of the podcasts I follow puts this eloquently; there is what the character wants, and what the character needs. Surely you’ve seen this movie. The hero is pursuing the seemingly unobtainable girl of his dreams, a haughty, pampered princess. He struggles to better himself and to become worthy of her notice, slowly achieving success and self-esteem — all the while with the support and encouragement of the tomboy he’s known since childhood, the tomboy who… Oh, you figured out where this was going already. There are endless variations on this. A protagonist doesn’t have to grow and change. But in many of the good stories, they do. They set out with a goal of petty revenge and end up leading a revolution. They seek out the man who killed their father and find out it wasn’t him after all — but now he has help finding the real killer. Heck, Dorothy sings about wanting to leave home. And the moment she finds out about what the Ruby Slippers do, “There’s no place like home!”
